title: Not All Moods are Created Equal! Exploring Human Emotional States in Social Media

author: Munmun De Choudhury, College of Computing, Georgia Institute of Technology

segmentation: Hello everyone, good morning and I'm 11 Microsoft Research and I'm going to be talking about moods today in the context of social media.
This is a joint work with Scott counts.
Who is right up there in the audience and Michael Gamon also from Microsoft Research.
So we'll start with.
A small quiz.
How many of you can recognize that picture up in the slide?
Raise your hands.
OK, great fair enough for the rest of us.
This is this picture is a part of a Seminole work by psychologist Paul Ekman who tried to study moods, characterization of moods based on facial expressions of people, and what you found interesting.
Lee was that moods can be characterized into these six different types.
And these moods were fairly consistent across individuals coming from different types of social contexts, and even different cultures.
So what are these?

Moods, after all, so modes are very complex, psychophysiological, and reactions of our interactions with our environment, which could be internal stimuli as well as well as external stimuli related to our social context.

A bit from Paul Ekman's time to the current time, things haven't.
I changed much because all of us from all over the world.

Especially with platforms like Twitter, we.

So the goal of the.
Paper was to start to understand the landscape of moods and social media and how that relates to our social and behavioral attributes.
So to start with, let us take a look.
What has been done in that area before?
In the social media community.
Moods and emotions are not new.

In fact, there is a lot of interest in understanding sentiment, in particular around a variety of utility tasks, including classification and so forth, and even a lot of work has been done in trying to understand mood trends around a variety of events.
In trying to understand the temporal trends around seasons, culture, and so forth.
A common thread in all that work has been that researchers have been looking at.
Emotion from 2 broad categories that being positive affect and negative affect.
However, the moment we start to think about human behavior, we realize that positive and negative affect are actually not enough.
Human emotion is much more complex, and in order to make sense of our behavior, it is very important for us to start to appreciate that our moods can be very fine grained and nuanced.
So what do we do?
We go back to Paul Ekman's time back in like three decades for four decades back.
And we look at some literature on in psychology and what we find that there has been a lot of work in trying to understand and characterize these modes along various types and classes.

Apart from Ekman's work that there has been work on categorizing, categorizing moods into six different types, called the profile of mood states for example as well as there's been work on defining different types of emotional models that characterizes moods along different scales such as pleasure, displeasure, arousal, non arousal, dominance, submissiveness, and so forth.
Inaudible our work has also been the circumplex of representation of human moods in the.
Side of two measures called the Veillance an activation.

Social metric instrument that has been used by psychologists to understand emotions in a much fine, grain, nuanced manner.

So Quadrant 1 one is high valence on high activation modes, where is quadrant three is low balance and lower activation modes.

We were extremely excited about this idea and we moved on to even thinking about.

83% of the cases the crowd workers found to be like actually reflective of the persons mode.

The mood could have been present anywhere in the Cretan that didn't seem to perform that well.

This particular question was to ask are more social people happier or not?
So what to answer that question?
What we did was to come up with this measure called sociality.
Sociality is a function that we defined to be proportional to the ratio of the number of followers or in links to and the number of followers or out links of a person.
So in some sense it is very simple signal that tells you about a person's ego network and what we did was on the circumplex.
We plotted these moods based on the sociality of the people sharing that.

The green ones are the people with sociality close to 1.
The red ones are very low values and the blue ones are very high.
You'll see a great large number of green moods.
That are appearing on the right side of the circle.

So in some sense people with Asociality close to one seem to be expressing a large number of happy modes, so our conjecture is that someone who is the person with Asociality close to one, it's probably the average Twitter user who has, you know, decent number of followers, a decent number of followees, which means that the person is trying to grab attention from certain people.
And the person is also broadcasting their updates to a similar number of people.
So it turns out if that is really the measure of the normal Twitter user who can be probably social, then we see that.

We looked at another social attribute of people, which is the degree of.
Activity.

Which is that people who are quite active?

Studies we found a lot of interesting insights, some of which are supported by grounded findings in psychology, which were performed in smaller groups of people.
